entry.title: HR Efficiency in Action: Automate and Streamline HR Processes
entry.content:
HR teams today are under more pressure than ever. They must support global workforces, ensure compliance, respond to business change, and still deliver a great employee experience. Yet, many HR processes remain manual, repetitive, or fragmented, slowing down operations and leaving little time for strategic work.

SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central offers practical, high-impact tools to simplify processes, automate routine tasks, and empower employees and managers to take more control. Best of all, many of these capabilities can be enabled quickly without major transformation projects, giving you ‘Quick Wins’!  This blog explores a practical framework for scaling HR efficiency.

Simplify, Automate, Empower: The HR Efficiency Framework

The path to a more efficient HR function can be broken into three focus areas:

1. Simplification

Simplification means reducing manual steps and making processes more intuitive for both HR and managers. It’s about removing friction, standardizing where possible, and giving HR teams tools that are easier to use.

Key examples include:

  • Configurable Hire Templates: Hiring should adapt to different needs, not force a one-size-fits-all process. With configurable templates, HR can tailor data collection by country, employment type, or business unit. For example, you may not need bank details for contingent workers, or dependent data in certain countries. Templates ensure only relevant data is captured, reducing errors and saving time. They also support custom fields and objects, so unique organizational needs can be addressed without customization.
  • Mass Data Changes: HR teams often need to update records for hundreds of employees at once; for reorgs, policy updates, contract changes., etc.  SuccessFactors offers multiple tools to manage bulk updates:
    • Mass Data Management: A user-friendly interface to filter, preview, and update positions or employee job information in bulk; without Excel files.
    • Manage Mass Changes: Ideal for more complex updates to employee Job Information or Job Relationships, using groups and batch jobs.
    • Manage Mass Changes for Metadata Objects: Uses business rules to apply logic-driven updates to Positions and other objects – for example., changing departments based on grade and location.
    • Integration Center: Build and schedule automated data flows between SuccessFactors and other systems.
    • Data Imports: The tried-and-true method using templates to load and/or update employee or foundation data.

Together, these tools give HR flexibility to match the method to the scenario; from quick fixes to large-scale changes.

  • Add New Employee to This Position: A small but powerful feature, this allows hiring to start directly from an open position in the Position Org Chart. Relevant details from the position (like company, location, or cost center) flow into the new hire record, cutting re-entry and reducing errors.
  • Custom Home Page Cards: Employees don’t usually log in daily, so making key information visible matters. Custom cards let HR share reminders, campaigns, or quick links directly on the homepage. They’re easy to configure and a great way to keep employees engaged with minimal effort.

2. Automation

Where simplification removes steps, automation removes work altogether. Automating repetitive processes not only saves time but also improves consistency and compliance.

Practical examples include:

  • Automatic Hire: Once candidate data is captured in Recruiting or Onboarding, SuccessFactors can move it directly into Employee Central without manual intervention. HR can set rules so only complete or validated candidates are processed automatically, while exceptions still route to Manage Pending Hires. This reduces admin overhead and speeds up onboarding.
  • Effective Workflow Processing: Approvals are critical for governance but can easily become bottlenecks. SuccessFactors workflows now offer:
    • Auto-delegation groups: Managers can delegate different workflows to different people (e.g., time approvals to an admin, pay changes to a senior manager).
    • Workflow Professional Edition: HR can reassign, resend, or mass approve workflows without IT help.
    • Microsoft Teams Integration: Approvals can be completed directly in Teams, speeding up decision-making and reducing HR follow-up.
  • Document Generation: Employment letters, verification statements, and other documents can be generated in bulk or on demand; by employees, managers, or HR. Instead of waiting on HR services, employees can self-serve common requests like proof of employment. Managers can generate promotion or probation letters instantly. HR can bulk-generate bonus or termination letters. This reduces admin workload and provides faster service to employees.   

 

3. Empowerment

The third lever of HR efficiency is empowerment: giving employees and managers the tools to self-serve, find answers, and act without relying on HR every time.

Examples include:

  • Joule AI: The conversational AI copilot embedded in SuccessFactors. Joule can:
    • Complete tasks like changing addresses or approving workflows (transactional support).
    • Guide users to the right page (navigational help).
    • Answer questions about HR policies or leave balances (informational help).

Available on desktop and mobile, Joule reduces HR service desk tickets and improves the employee experience by providing instant, accurate help.

  • Document Grounding: Joule’s answers are backed by your organization’s own policy documents. For example, if an employee asks about parental leave, Joule will reference your own HR policy, provide a summary, and link to the source. This builds trust and ensures answers are accurate.

 

Why This Matters

The case for HR efficiency isn’t just about saving time. It’s about enabling HR to do its real job: building people strategies that drive business success.  Many organizations are underusing automation and AI. This leads to inefficiencies, errors, and limited scalability, particularly for global organizations.

By embracing quick wins like configurable templates, bulk updates, streamlined workflows, and AI-powered self-service, HR can free up hours of manual work each week, improve data quality, and deliver a smoother experience for employees.

For more information, examples of quick wins, please view our recent Webinar, including recording, slides: 

Webinar: HR Efficiency in Action - Recording and Slides

entry.title: Mass Data Management extended to support Job Relationships
entry.content:
In H2 2025 release the Mass Data Management tool will be extended to include Job Relationship to support Job information and Positions.

Processing mass transactions is critical for any organization irrespective of the size. Being able to support mass changes to job relationships is key to supporting this.

Even if you have already configured the Mass Data Management object for positions and job information you will need to do this for Job Relationships.

Once it is configured create a Mass Change in Mass Data Management, selecting the Job Relationship you would like to update.

This will then show you all the people ‘Tessa Walker’ is the HR Manager for.

You can select the employees you wish to update, then click edit.

Search for the employee who will be the new HR Manager and click apply.  This will create the draft.

 

You can the review the changes and submit the request.

For Jeffrey Hilton we now see that the HR Manager has been updated accordingly.

This is a valuable new feature added to Mass Data Management tool. 

Before you use the feature you need to consider how you are using matrix relationships as this should be the source of data not job relationships. Furthermore, you should also review the settings for hierarchy adaption in position management setting as well as this could reverse any changes made in job relationships.

entry.title: Rethinking SAP SuccessFactors Org Design in the Age of Skills-Based Organizations
entry.content:
From Hierarchies to Capabilities: Rethinking SAP SuccessFactors Org Design in the Age of Skills-Based Organizations

Not long ago, an organization’s design could be read right off the walls of its office building: departments physically clustered together, managers’ names on doors, and reporting lines as rigid as the floor plan itself. HR organizational structures, reflected in systems such as SAP HCM, mirrored this reality by modeling companies as networks of organizational units, with a chief position heading each department.

These structures met the needs of their time, establishing reporting lines and headcount allocations around departmental boundaries, and generating organograms that depicted the company in a rigid, top-down view. In an era of stability and predictability, this approach worked. But the world of work has changed and so must our approach to HR organizational design.Today’s enterprises are shifting toward role-driven and increasingly skills-based models that foster agility, transparency, and a tighter alignment between workforce capabilities and business strategies that continuously adapt to changing business realities.

Yet many organizations still hold on to outdated ways of working in HR org design, forcing current needs into legacy concepts within today’s modern systems like SAP SuccessFactors. The consequence is unnecessary complexity, configurations that diverge from modern leading practices, limited use of standard features, and - most importantly - a missed opportunity to embrace a future-proof design philosophy.

This blog explores why it’s time to let go of legacy concepts, why positions, roles and skills should form the backbone of modern HR org design, and how to approach this shift in practice, for example when preparing for a SAP SuccessFactors implementation.

Clarifying the purpose of an HR organizational structure

Before rethinking how to best reflect your organization in a new HRIS system like SAP SuccessFactors, it’s important to step back from systems for a moment, and answer the question: what business purposes should an organizational structure serve today? At its core, it should enable:

 


Clarity of accountability: define who manages whom, and where primary supervisory responsibilities are placed. 

Functional identity: making it clear which teams or units serve which purpose in the enterprise

Operational transparency: providing senior leaders and employees visibility into how teams are grouped and connected from a workforce perspective.

Strategic adaptability: supporting planning, restructuring, and workforce reallocation when business priorities shift.

Communication and community: offering employees a sense of belonging to a recognized team or function.

 


These needs are universal, but the way they are fulfilled in HR context is fundamentally changing.

Adapting the workforce and how their skills are applied to meet shifting business needs must now be front and center. Today, organizational entities are best understood as groups of people with certain skills brought together to deliver a specific functional capability or set of capabilities to drive a certain outcome. In this sense, HR structures are less about static boxes, job titles and formal education, more about how people are grouped, managed and equiped to take on evolving tasks. Drawing strict lines around these groups, in the form of departments should in that sense become less relevant; in fact, trying to maintain departments in lockstep with every operational change, introduces unnecessary complexity and creates significant maintenance overhead.

Translating HR business needs into modern org design principles

If we take today’s HR business requirements seriously, certain organizational design principles emerge. These principles build on the distinction between functional groupings, positions, jobs, roles, and skills, each serving a different purpose in how organizations are structured and how work gets done:

  1. Anchor HR org design in business clarity, not legacy habits.
    When transitioning to a new system like SAP SuccessFactors, revisit the true, forward-looking business purposes of organizational structures and translate them into modern concepts and system design. Too often, legacy constructs such as those from SAP HCM OM are taken for granted as “business requirements” for the new system, without recognizing that they were originally also solution design choices and not carved-in-rock business necessities.
  2. Separate functional and operational dimensions.
    Functional groupings define how people and positions are organized around a shared mission or business purpose (e.g., a product line, sales organization, services, or center of expertise). Labels might change over time, but in essence they tend to be stable entities, providing continuity and identity over time. Typically these groupings are reflected in the Company Structure. Operational structures, on the other hand, determine how people are grouped to execute the work and define who manages whom. These structures are dynamic, shifting as teams, reporting lines, and spans of control evolve with business needs. This is typically reflected in the People Org Chart, based on people holding certain positions.
  3. Keep HR reporting lines position-driven.
    A position represents a unique "seat" in the structure, tied to a specific line manager and place in the hierarchy. Using a position-to-position hierarchy as the single source of truth for primary reporting lines, ensures clarity and consistency in how these are defined and maintained. This hierarchy should drive all core HR processes, from approvals and workflow routing to role-based permissions and HR analytics. Other attributes such as Business Units, Divisions and Departments are supporting elements in processing and reporting, but they should not replace the position hierarchy as the backbone of managerial relationships.
  4. Keep HR and Financial structures distinct.
    HR organizational design should focus on people management, functional identity, and workforce capabilities, while financial structures (such as cost centers or profit centers) serve budgeting, accounting, and financial control purposes. The two dimensions serve very different business needs, should not be forced into a single hierarchy, nor should the one dictate the other. Instead, it should be sufficient to connect them through clear integration points, for example, by linking positions or employees to cost centers so that workforce data can inform financial planning without constraining HR structures and the other way around.
  5. Define jobs as the employment anchor.
    A job defines what a person is formally hired into, capturing employment expectations, qualifications, pay structures, and key traits. It provides stability and consistency for HR processes such as recruiting, compensation, compliance, and career frameworks. However, jobs are not meant to dictate the actual, ever-evolving work carried out to achieve specific business outcomes. Instead, they serve as a stable reference point that ensures fairness and comparibility, while leaving flexibility to roles and skills to define what work is performed in practice.
  6. Use a role concept to reflect the work actually performed.
    A role represents a set of logically grouped capabilities and defines what a person executing on that role is expected to do in practice within a functional entity, in conjuntion and collaboration with other roles in the same context. One individual may execute multiple roles depending on projects and business needs (e.g., Functional Consultant, Solution Architect, Project Manager or Business Manager). Roles should be reflected in compentency models and skills taxonomies and provide the ultimate flexibility to react to changing needs and are the bridge to a skills-based view.
  7. Leverage skills as the adaptive layer.
    Skills cut across jobs, roles, and positions. They describe the actual capabilities people bring, and they enable operational workforce planning, project staffing, career development, and skill gap closure strategies, independently from the org structure. In modern organizations, these skills have become the true currency of agility, enabling companies to dynamically match talent with work as needs evolve. Skills taxonomies provide the framework to make this real.
  8. Support advanced needs with dedicated tools.
    Scenario planning, reorganizations, and rich visualizations should be supported through dedicated HR planning and analytics tools, like SAP Workforce Planning and Analytics, rather than forcing complexity and customization into the core EC  model. This keeps the foundation lean and aligned with clean-core principles.

Building for the future

Modern HR org design is about agility, clarity, and purpose, and it continues to evolve. By letting positions drive HR reporting lines, keeping the functional structure lean and aligned with real business needs, and leveraging roles and skills as the true connectors between people and work, organizations can simplify their structures while enhancing transparency and adaptability.

Looking ahead, the evolution does not stop here. Many organizations are experimenting with dynamic teams, temporary or cross-functional groups formed around specific business outcomes and dissolved once those outcomes are achieved. Dynamic teams build on the same foundation: positions provide the reporting anchor, jobs define the employment context, roles capture the contributions people make, and skills determine the best fit between talent and work. By embedding team formation in this model, enterprises can embrace agility and innovation without creating parallel hierarchies or adding unnecessary complexity to the core structure.

The result is a design philosophy that not only aligns with modern HR systems such as SuccessFactors but also equips the business to adapt and thrive in a world where change is constant and skills are the true currency of success.

Curious about how these concepts translate into your own SAP SuccessFactors environment?  SAP Services can help!

Josephine Damen, HR Business Architect
HR Innovation and Transformation
Adoption Services Center, SAP SuccesFactors HCM

entry.title: SuccessFactors Payroll Result(Pay-slip) Integration Guide with Third Party Payroll System
entry.content:
This post shares a practical integration case on SuccessFactors MDF Payroll Result (Pay-slip) Integration. It covers how to design MDF objects to store pay-slip data from third-party payroll systems, the integration architecture, and global payroll result analysis design, along with key considerations and limitations. While it appears simple, complexity arises with large data volumes, multiple payroll systems, and diverse data structures.

Background

In this case, the customer is a multinational enterprise using SuccessFactors as a global HRIS, but with different payroll systems per region. As payroll data resides in local systems, the headquarters lacked consolidated insight into workforce costs, limiting analytics and planning. Therefore, centralizing payroll data became essential.

  • Global HRIS: SAP SuccessFactors(Employee Master Data Source)

  • Third-party payroll systems:

    • ADP (US, Mexico)
    • BIPO (APAC: Singapore, Thailand, Vietnam)
    • Payroll B (Germany)

The flow is bidirectional — employee master data moves from SAP SuccessFactors to payroll systems, and pay-slip data flows back into SuccessFactors.

Integration Center / SFTP acts as the middleware.

Pay results land in MDF objects (PayResultParent, PayResultItem) and feed into Story / People Analytics for HQ insights.

Business Requirement Analysis

The table below summarizes the requirements, reasoning, implementation approach, and complexity level.

• purgeType=full for child MDF in Integration Center		5Avoid pushing zero-amount records and invalid record — it creates excessive invalid data.

Integration Design

Payroll data can be integrated via API or SFTP.
SFTP is generally recommended because it is auditable (via stored flat files), simple in structure, and suitable for low-frequency data transfers (weekly or monthly).

1. API Integration

In case API integration is required due to security necessity or other, I also introduce API-based integration menthod. In this method, avoid inserting parent and child MDF records in one request. Use two separate upsert requests — one for the parent and another for the child — for clarity, completeness, and broader parameter support. Below is a example of single MDF payload request:

    "uri": "https://api4preview.sapsf.com/odata/v2/PaymentInformationV3",
    "type": "SFOData.PaymentInformationV3"
  },

  "worker": "Berg01",

      },
      {

          "type": "SFOData.PaymentInformationDetailV3"
        },
        "PaymentInformationV3_effectiveStartDate": "/Date(1753432694289)/",

Parent–child MDF integration cannot be handled in a single job. Below shows the comparison of purge types in different operation environment for referrence:

In addition, it is recommended to set source page size to '1000' to make it stable and efficient.

Story and Analysis

Currency Exchange:
Avoid calculating via Story Concatenation Columns — large datasets exceed system limits.
Refer to Guardrails for People Analytics Story and SAP Note 3025688.
Each query supports:

  • Up to 120 columns
  • 30 tables
  • 1,000,000 cells per query

Monthly Aggregation:
To analyze sums per month, use a calculated column (Payroll Month) to convert MM/DD/YYYY → YYYY-MM with Year() and Month() functions.
This handles varying pay frequencies (e.g., bi-weekly in the US vs. monthly in Singapore) efficiently via pivot aggregation.

Historical Record Retrieval:
Use Time Filter for all historical MDF data but “Today” filters for navigation tables (Job Info, Personal Info, etc.) to avoid duplication and incorrect joins.

Summary

This project demonstrates a complex yet practical scenario integrating MDF, API, Integration Center, and Story Reporting. The challenges stemmed from data volume, multiple payroll systems, and sensitivity concerns. It took approximately two months for me to complete the full implementation, so I hope that this guide helps you reduce your learning curve for similar integration requirements.
For detailed questions or discussion, feel free to comment below or contact me in LinkedIn.

entry.title: Company Structure Overview and duplicate objects displayed
entry.content:
Let's start by defining our Company Structure, usually we find the Business Unit as the highest level in the hierarchy, followed by the Divisions and the rest of the structure is defined using parent child department relationship.

In this scenario our department object will have 2 associations one to division and another one to parent department. 

Because the Company Structure overview relays on the associations to display the structure, the department will be displayed twice, once under the division and another one under the parent department.

Department configuration

Let me show you a workaround to avoid this duplication

1. Add a custom field - division on Department object. this field should be read only

2. We create a Rule triggered on Save on Department object, that automatically populates the data from the standard association field to the new custom_division field in case the Parent department value is null

The custom division field should only be updated in case the Parent Department is not empty

3. Update the Company Structure Overview to display the new field instead of standard association

4. Go to Company Structure Overview and display the results. The Department no longer appear duplicated

5. Position and job info filters to departments will remain the same

Hope this can make your Company Structure easier to set up and maintain 

Please also take into consideration the useful information and configurations shared on IDP ( implementation Design Principle) IDP Employee Central Core Hybrid - Organization Structure Design Consideration V2.0.pdf

This IDP will provide you also more clarity on the set up and design of the Organization Structure

entry.title: SuccessFactors Work Tech - Microsoft Teams App Major Updates for 2H 2025
entry.content:
Feature Name Update in What’s New

In 2023, we've released an SuccessFactors App for Microsoft Teams to bring most of the SuccessFactors Quick Actions/Notifications into MS Teams to improve working and collaboration efficiency of employees' life (E2E Demo for major features of the app).  To help you find the right feature more efficiently in the What’s New for each release's new enhancement, we’ve changed our Feature Name from “Work Tech” to “Work Tech (Microsoft Teams Integration)". See below screenshot:

Feature Switch Available

This is a highly requested feature by many customers. We have a lot of quick actions and notifications/approvals in our Teams app. Some customers might only want to start with part of them and then gradually enable more, not all at once. Now with this enhancement, we'll add the Switches for quick actions and notification cards, to provide flexibility to control which quick actions/ which approvals to be on/off based on your own company's strategy. See more details in the What's New.

It's quite easy to do the configuration, just go to Admin Center > Work Tech Configuration > Settings > SAP SuccessFactors APP in Teams. 

Note:

  • If a specific quick action is turned off, the action from the quick action list card and home tab will not be displayed, and user cannot trigger it via command in the chatbot as well.​
  • If a specific notification/approval card is turned off, it will not be sent to users’ chatbot as a reminder. But the historical cards remain there.
  • We have Quick Actions/Notification cards that are reused from SuccessFactors Home Page side. For those cards, if the card is disabled in Manage Home Page, it will be displayed as switched off and cannot be turned on in Work Tech side. So in order to use the same card in Teams App, go to Manage Home Page to enable it first if the card exists in Home Page. But if it's enabled in Home Page of SuccessFactors, you can freely turn it on/off specifically in Teams side. ​​

 

Long-Time Login Enhancement

Previously, users might be frequently asked to log in to their SAP SuccessFactors account when using some quick actions or accessing the Home tab (almost every 30 minutes based on SuccessFactors side session). We fully understand the concern and worked with our authentication team together to get it resolved finally.  With this enhancement, users can keep logged in for up to 3 months without needing to re-authenticate. And this is supported in both the desktop and mobile clients of Microsoft Teams. See more details in the What's New.
The only pre-condition is - The Identity and Access Management solution is enabled in your company.

Note:

  • The refresh token expiration time (3 months) cannot be set in the sub-application in IAS due to IAS current capability. It is entirely controlled by the parent. So after 3 months, user need to re-login again, then it will keep another 3 months again without login.
  • We'll start the enablement of this enhancement from mid Oct, not based on the code release cycle as it's controlled by a feature toggle so we'll enable as early as possible to improve your users' experience.

​

  • Demo Recording for how to enable the App
  • Guide for how to enable the App

entry.title: Dynamic Pictures (Headers/Footers) on Document Generation Template (SF Employee Central)
entry.content:
Dear All,

I recently worked on a use‐case in Employee Central’s document generation tool where the client needed dynamic headers, footers, and signatures to vary based on the legal entity. The twist? The documents must remain in the same format across entities.

After researching blogs, troubleshooting, and consulting an SAP expert, I landed on a solution that allows the system to automatically insert the correct logo or image when an employee generates a document. Below is how it works:(After 2505 Release)

SOLUTION:

Step 1: Insert all your Images into a single Document Template (For e.g. for Header you can create a Header template and save all your header images in Header Template, similarly for Footer you can create another template with naming Footer and save all your Footer images into that Template):

There are two options available for inserting all your images into a single document template

Option A: Drag and drop the image to the Template

  • Save the images into your local drive
  • Drop or Simply Copy & paste the image into the document generation template.
  • Select that particular image and click the additional options (three dots) from the menu.
  • From the menu, choose Insert/edit Image.
  • Copy the Source URL (e.g., data: image/jpeg; base64, XXXXXXXXXXXX) that is generated when an image is dropped.
  • Save the template.

Option B: Insert the link to add image to the template (Preferred Option)

  • Click on the three dots of the editor from the menu.
  • Select Insert/Edit Image

  • Add the image URL (You can raise a ticket with SAP to host the images into SAP/SF Server to generate a URL of the images)

  • Set description (if required) and adjust the dimensions
  • Click Ok and save the template.

Step 2: Create Letter Content and Insert the Image Placeholder in Next/Another New Template:

  • In this template, you can insert your content along with image placeholders.
  • Open another new document template where you want to insert the image
  • Click the additional options (three dots) menu again.
  • Select Insert/Edit Image.
  • Type the placeholder only in Source URL. (For ex. [[Header]])
  • Set the Dimensions

  • Click on OK and Save the template (Once the template saved, URL will auto generate)
  • Post Save, the template will look something like below

Step 3: Write the Business Rule:

  • Go to Configure Business Rule Configuration section & create a rule with a scenario: Document Generation Template Mapping Rule and Select Object 1 as “Job Information”

  • Choose your if conditions (based on client requirement) and set your then condition. In Set condition map the copied Source URL (the link generated in Step 1), similar way we can write if else statement.
  • Save the business rule.

Step 4: Assign Rule to Placeholder:

  • Navigate to Manage Document Template Mapping.
  • Search for that particular Document Template created in Step 2
  • Assign the business rule to the corresponding placeholder[[Header]] or [[Footer]] in the template.

 

CONCLUSION:

So, at last, I’ve been able to deliver dynamic headers and footers to meet customer expectations.

Now — what did you think of this post? Were the concepts clear? I’d love to hear your feedback or questions in the comments.”

entry.title: Field Level Infotype Update with Business Integration Builder
entry.content:
Business Problem

SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central (EC) serves as the system of record for core HR data, including the attributes necessary to manage an employee’s lifecycle processes, such as hiring, changes in job and personal information, and more. In contrast, the payroll system is responsible for managing compliance-related data, including tax details, social insurance information, garnishments, and other statutory or regulatory requirements.

Employee data maintained in SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central is replicated to the relevant Infotypes in SAP ERP HCM or SAP S/4 HANA. A single Infotype could have some fields being replicated from Employee central and a few payroll relevant fields that are not captured in Employee Central. Previously if such payroll relevant data was manually entered in SAP ERP HCM or SAP S/4 HANA for fields belonging to an Infotype which is replicated from Employee Central, then manual entries was overwritten the next time data was replicated from Employee Central. 

Let’s take an example with Infotype 0016 (Contract Elements). Contract Type (CTTYP) field of Infotype 0016 is available in Employee Central whereas payroll relevant fields Sick Pay Supplement Period Number (KGZFR) and Sick Pay Supplement Period Unit (KGZZH) missing in Employee Central is maintained in SAP S/4 HANA. 

Consider the following sequence of actions :-

  1. Hire an employee in Germany effective January 1, 2024, assigning Contract Type as Permanent.                                                                                                                                                                                               
  2. After replication, enter the following values directly into Infotype 0016 in the Payroll system (PA30 or Infotype UI mashups):
    • Sick Pay Supplement Period Number: 3
    • Sick Pay Supplement Period Unit: months                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              
  3. Update the employee’s contract type to Part-time in EC by creating a new record in Job Information, effective from June 1, 2024.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       
  4. After the next replication:
    • A new time slice is created in Infotype 0016, effective from June 1, 2024, with the Contract Type updated to Part-time.
    • The existing values of KGZFR and KGZFH fields in Infotype 0016 are cleared out both in the existing time-slice on January 1, 2024 and in the new record created on June 1, 2024.

As a result, customers often had to exclude such Infotypes from their replication scope and maintain them completely in the backend Payroll system either by using SAP GUI transactions or UI mashups. With this approach customers were unable to use the full flexibility of Employee Central as the modern cloud based HR system.

Field Level Infotype Update : Solution Overview

Employee master data replication from Employee Central using Business Integration Builder (BIB) now supports Field-Level Infotype Updates, enabling the partial replication of Infotype data from Employee Central without overwriting payroll-relevant Infotype fields maintained in SAP ERP HCM or SAP S/4 HANA.

Due to this newly introduced flexibility in master data replication, the data cut can now be configured at Infotype field level. You can now use Employee Central to maintain data of the available fields while entering the missing payroll-relevant fields of that infotype in SAP ERP HCM or SAP S/4HANA, either by using SAP GUI transactions or infotype UI mashups. The replication preserves existing payroll-related data, merges it with the incoming data from Employee Central, and updates the infotype with the combined details. 

In the same scenario described above, when contract type is updated from Permanent to Part Time in Employee Central and the Sick Pay Supplement Period details already exist in SAP S/4HANA, the outcome after replication is as follows :-

    • A new time slice is created in Infotype 0016, effective from June 1, 2024, with the Contract Type updated to Part-time.                                      
    • The existing values of KGZFR and KGZFH fields are retained in the existing time-slice and carry forwarded to the new time-slice effective from June 1, 2024.

The following visual illustrates how BIB replication works now with Field Level Infotype Update :-

Key Benefits

  • Maximize Cloud Capabilities: Extend your cloud footprint by leveraging the full potential of Employee Central as the core HR system of record.
  • Reduce Operational Costs  : Avoid embedding complex business logic or unnecessary custom fields in Employee Central for data that belongs to Payroll domain and not relevant for running core HR business processes.
  • Establish Role-Based Data Governance : Establish clear boundaries between HR and Payroll teams, allowing each to manage data relevant to their domain, improving governance and operational efficiency.
  • Seamless Data Continuity During Payroll System Upgrade : A consistent data cut between Core HR and Payroll ensures a smooth and reliable transition from SAP ERP HCM to SAP S/4 HANA on-premise or SAP S/4 HANA Private Cloud Edition.

Solution Status and Scope for 2H 2025

This feature of partial replication with field level Infotype update generally available with 2H 2025 release in :-

  • Support Package 40 of SFSF EC INTEGRATION (PA_SE_IN) add-on
  • Support Package 06 of SFSF EC S4 HCM INTEGRATION (ECS4HCM) add-on

For more details, refer to the What's New Viewer, ECS4HCM Help Guide, PA_SE_IN Help Guide.

The payroll relevant fields can now be protected during replication for the following Infotypes and their corresponding secondary Infotypes :-

  • Infotype 0001 (Organizational Assignment)
  • Infotype 0016 (Contract Elements)

This feature is intended for customers running payroll in SAP ERP HCM or SAP S/4HANA who are either beginning their Employee Central implementation or have already implemented it and want to broaden its usage scope.

To preserve historical Infotype data maintained in SAP ERP HCM or SAP S/4 HANA, it is recommended to use Field Level Infotype Update in combination with Infotype Specific Full Transmission Start Date functionality that is also introduced in 2H 2025.

Configuration Requirements

  • Set the constant value of EC to ERP: Don't overwrite Payroll related Infotype fields option in view  V_ECPAO_CONSTANTS to X.
  • Define the payroll-relevant fields of Infotype 0001 (Org Assignment) and Infotype 0016 (Contract Elements) that should be protected during employee master data replication from Employee Central, using the view ECPAO_INFTY_FLD available under Customizing for Business Integration Builder as shown below :-                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   

The below configuration ensures that fields KGZFR (Sick Pay Supplement Period Number) and KGZZH (Sick Pay Supplement Period Unit) are protected during replication for employees belonging to Germany.

Subtypes and Country Grouping fields are optional. If a particular field is relevant for all countries, then this should be empty.

Fields belonging to Custom Includes can be included in this customizing for Field Level Infotype Update and protected during replication.

If an Infotype field is already mapped in the Transformation Template Group used for employee data replication, it should not be included in the Field-Level Infotype Update configuration. Doing so will cause replication errors due to data conflicts.

Additionally, it is recommended to exclude Infotype fields that are derived by the HCM Framework.

Conclusion: 

We truly value your feedback on this new functionality and would love to hear your thoughts on which additional Infotypes you would like to see supported, beyond Infotype 0001 (Organizational Assignment) and Infotype 0016 (Contract Elements).

Please feel free to share your suggestions, requirements, or expectations in the comments section. Your input plays a key role in shaping future enhancements, and we look forward to collaborating with you to improve our solution.

entry.title: Beyond Manual: SuccessFactors Custom MDF & Integration Center for Automated Reimbursement Process
entry.content:
Symptoms:
 In mid-to-large sized companies, HR officers often face a lot of challenges managing the reimbursement Requests raised each month. This process can become time consuming and labor intensive due to the variety of request types and calculation rules (business travel, visa charges…).
commonly these requests are submitted by email. After that the approval and the data entry into the payroll system will be performed manually. However, this will always lead to delayed payments and increased errors.
Process flow:

 


                                                                                                                             

Concept:
For a smoother and streamlined process, we must implement a fully automated solution, consider implementing a custom MDF object within SuccessFactors for each reimbursement category, for centralized payments governance.
 Yet, this solution will only cover Step 1 and 2 of the process flow. ⚠️

Limitations:
Data circulation from custom MDF objects to the standard SuccessFactors objects, is not supported using business rules (refer to SAP KBA 2562069 for details).

✅Standards to Custom MDF => Data propagation allowed via Business Rules
❌Custom MDF to Standards => Data propagation NOT allowed via Business Rules

Enhancement:
To cover the last step of the process flow (posting payments to payroll) and further enable full automation. We need to create an internal Integration Job using the SuccessFactors Integration Center (IC).

In the following section, we will guide you through the exact IC configuration steps.

How to map?

Search Integration Center, My Integrations => Create => More Integration Types.

 


To fill data into One-Time Payments (which is standard portlet), use a scheduled Integration Center job. Then Select all required fields, as framed in the screenshot below.

1.Select the Data Source: (Custom MDF object)
Search for your cust_MDF => Select

2.Select the Target object: (Standard Object)
Click Add Button

Search the Target MDF object (Non-Recurring Payments) => Select the destination Fields one after the other.

From the right corner, choose the mapping type for the fields(based on your need):

  • Set as Fixed Value Field: Used to Give fixed value to the destination field (e.g. Fixed payment type or currency).
  • Set as Association Field: Used to Directly get data from your Source Object. Drag the source field and drop it into the desired Target Field (e.g. The Total payment amount, the creation date…).
  • Set as Calculation Field: Used to Dynamically fill Data into the Target field based on data from 1 or more Source Fields. (e.g. generation of payment amounts using predefined formula rather than direct mapping).

3.Add filters and sorts: (Optional But Important⚠️)

First, we need to understand what are the different types of filters that we have:
a. Advanced Filters: Used to specify more complex conditional expressions than are  possible with the simple filters.
b. Time-Based Filters: Helps to get all the records (current and/or historical) that have been modified since the last time the integration ran.
c. Advanced Sorting: Used to sort the output records.”
 Source(https://help.sap.com/docs/successfactors-platform/using-integration-center/filter-and-sort)
In our case will need to apply Time-Based Filter=>"Effective From Date", because we need to read and propagate all New, Old, and/or Changed records, not just the latest one.
(for more details please refer to KBA 2470903)

Important Note: ⚠️⚠️
If approved records only need to be Auto-created under one-time payment, please ensure to enable the pending Data fields in your Source Object definition:
 1. Access "Configure Object Definitions.

 2. Search for your Source Cust-MDF object.

 3. set the "Pending Data field" to YES

This way we ensure that the Integration will consider the requests with Approved Status only.

4. Schedule your Integration, then review and save.


By reaching this stage, we have successfully implemented a fully automated reimbursement Process .

5. Reporting: (Optional But Important⚠️)

To verify and track data it’s recommended to create two reports using the report center:
 1. Reimbursement Requests per Type
 2. Non-Recurring payment amounts per Reimbursement type.

Conclusion:
Combining Custom MDF Objects with SuccessFactors Integration center can serve the organizations’ needs to overcome the Business rule limitation and fully automate the Data propagation from Custom to Standard Objects. This can be achieved with Simple Configuration steps Starting By creating new Integration type, Selecting the Source object (Custom MDF), Choosing the Target object (Standard MDF), then configuring the appropriate Field mapping (Fixed, association, or calculated), Optionally applying Filters and Sorting (Advanced, Time-based, …), and Finally Schedule the Job to run at your preferred Frequency. 

References:
2209164 - How to enable Integration Center in SuccessFactors System? - SAP SuccessFactors HXM Suite
2701195 - SuccessFactors to SuccessFactors integration - Integration Center
2655688 - How to Set a Schedule for Integration Center Jobs Using SuccessFactors Integration Center
2470903 - Integration Center is not returning historical/future records
2742107 - Integration Center: Frequently Asked Questions
2562069 - Scenario-based business rules for MDF objects, Parameters, Limitations, and other information about custom MDF Business Rule configuration scenario
https://help.sap.com/docs/successfactors-platform/using-integration-center/integration-center?locale...

entry.title: SAP SuccessFactors 2H 2025 Release: What’s New & What Matters
entry.content:
SAP’s H2 2025 SuccessFactors release isn’t chasing headlines, it’s about foundation. After the wave of Joule and AI announcements earlier this year, this release focuses on what truly matters for customers and partners: consistency, data quality, and modernization.

What this really means is that SAP is tightening every bolt, from the redesigned People Profile to the smallest validation rule - to make sure SuccessFactors can handle the next phase of intelligent, connected HXM.

Key Themes in the 2H 2025 Release

1️⃣  Full Profile redesign everywhere

The editing and history experiences in the latest People Profile have been completely reimagined. Dependents, contact data, and emergency information now follow the same modern pattern - intuitive, streamlined, and consistent.

2️⃣ Cleaner data and smarter rules

Across Employee Central, Time, and Benefits, SAP introduced tighter validations, better error handling, and enhanced rule contexts. This ensures data accuracy and consistency across modules.

3️⃣ Streamlined employment lifecycle

From hire to rehire, from job changes to terminations, the end-to-end employment process is smoother, more automated, and more predictable.

4️⃣ Extensibility-first mindset

The new Extensibility Wizard on SAP BTP is now generally available, simplifying in-app and side-by-side extensions - a key step toward modular innovation.

5️⃣ Legacy cleanup continues

SAP continues to retire older frameworks, including the legacy People Profile, YouCalc workflows, classic accrual methods, and outdated SOAP APIs.

Let’s start with my favorite, the heart of the SAP SuccessFactors HCM Suite.

Employee Central

Employee Central (EC) continues to mature with emphasis on data visibility, permissions, and accuracy.

  • New History UI of Full Profile: History UI for Full Profile provides more streamlined experience when you manage previous, current, and future records of effective-dated entities.
  • Position Management: new validations and configuration consistency : 💪
    • Validation of Event Reason with Position Reclassification Follow-Up Process
    • Error Messages for Missing Employee Central Event Publishing Configuration Object
    • Enhancements in Right to Return Configuration
    • Enhanced Position Validation when Hiring an Employee with a Fixed-Term Contract
    • Position Job Requisition Processing Job Type Moved to Scheduled Job Manager
    • Moving Positions When Changing An Employee's Manager Assignment available for Promotion, Demotion and Transfer Quick Actions
    • Defaulting of the Manager or Position and Hierarchy Adaptation After Imports for Termination imports
  • Quick Actions : define ESS/MSS templates by country for common tasks.
  • Inactive Employment Access : employees can now view data from inactive employments.
  • Talent Data Transfer : move an individual’s talent data from inactive to active employment in one go.
  • Customizable Alert Notifications Using Document Generation : Document template per language and link it to the new Alert category group.
  • Improved HRIS Sync : detailed execution logs in Scheduled Job Manager.
  • Enhanced Permission Roles for Accessing Employee Data During Rehire: Define target populations for rehiring inactive employees on old or new employment through the Duplicate Check.
  • New Work Order Requires New Employment : Concurrent Employment for Contingent Workers renamed toNew Work Order Requires New Employment.
  • Workflow Enhancements in Latest People Profile.
  • API Enhancements : customString1 and lastDateWorked now filterable in OData APIs; character-based length validation introduced.

The overall tone is clear -- EC is being refined for reliability and audit-readiness.

Onboarding

Onboarding continues its evolution toward clarity and compliance stability.

  • Automate Onboarding Initiation from Recruiting.
  • A clear banner reminds administrators that Onboarding 1.0 reaches end of maintenance in 2H 2025 and deletion in 1H 2026.
  • New Onboarding Featured Cards on the Latest Home Page.
  • Mandatory Event Reason for Onboarding Process Initiation.
  • Employer signature rules renamed for easier configuration.
  • Error messaging during E-Verify and document upload is now explicit and contextual.
  • Enhancements to the U.S.C.I.S. Form I-9 💪
  • Automate National ID Information Extraction in Onboarding via SAP Document AI
    • SAP Document AI, embedded edition can extract the following information from the National ID :
      • Country/Region
      • National ID Card Type
      • National ID (Number)
      • Valid to
      • Valid from
  • Retaining New Hire Personal Information During Automatic Restart of Onboarding Process.

These refinements make the Onboarding experience far less error-prone and fully aligned with the new People Profile design.

Recruiting

Recruiting receives a language and layout overhaul for usability and consistency.

  • .Applicant Filtering by Assessment Score and Recommendation.
  • Simplified button labels such as Add Competencies, Close, Add to Talent Pool.
  • Browser tab titles and menu structures standardized across Job Requisition and Applicant Management pages.
  • Breadcrumb navigation added for candidates in the new Candidate Experience.
  • Automatic Transfer of Recruiting Skills to Growth Portfolio 💪
    • Only skill names are transferred to the Growth Portfolio. Proficiency levels must be updated manually.
  • Clearer menu grouping — Manage Requisition, Manage Job Postings, Manage Applicants.
  • Candidate Profile Extension in the Redesigned Applicant Management Tool
  • Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) using Identity Authentication Service (IAS) for Agency Users.

Small changes, yes — but they bring a big impact in how recruiters and candidates experience the hiring process. The real story, though, is what’s happening behind the scenes: SAP’s acquisition of SmartRecruiters.

This move signals a clear intent to strengthen SuccessFactors’ end-to-end recruiting capabilities, especially around AI-driven sourcing, CRM-style candidate nurturing, and intelligent matching. Over time, expect deeper integration between SmartRecruiters’ talent acquisition engine and SuccessFactors Recruiting 😉, blurring the lines between applicant tracking and experience management.

In short, it’s a quiet update with major strategic depth - and definitely one to keep a close eye on.

Learning

Learning continues its modernization path with focus on data integrity and AI-aligned skill handling.

  • Numeric-only validation for cost and hour fields in External Learning Requests.
  • Skill Standardization via SAP Business AI : supports both standardized and alternate skill names in the taxonomy.
  • Peer comments and Suggested By now visible on the Course Home.
  • Bulk Delete Unused iContent Files From Learning Administration 💪
  • Updated labels: View More → Show More, Register Employees → Finish Registration, Recommend → Submit.
  • Fix for multiple employments – same course now appears under each employment with relevant action buttons.

These changes improve both the learner experience and data alignment for AI-based recommendations.

Time Management & Tracking

Time Management becomes even more compliance-ready and automated.

  • Geofencing for Clock Time 💪

    • Only Google Maps is currently supported to render the maps shown in the application. If Google Maps isn't supported in your country/region, then you won't be able to use the Geofencing feature.
  • Automatic recalculation for changes in Holiday Calendars.
  • Yearly view in team absence calendar
  • Absences in weeks (especially for Australian compliance).
  • FMLA Dashboard integration with third-party providers in the U.S.
  • Deduction field now separate from “Requesting” for better clarity.
  • Permanent time accounts now replicable to SAP Payroll.

Each of these refinements increases transparency and reliability in time processing.

People Profile & Mobile Experience

The People Profile transformation continues at full speed.

  • New Editing UI and History UI for Full Profile.
  • Dependents, emergency contacts, and personal data UIs redesigned for accuracy.
  • Validation ensures one dependent can be linked to only one employee.
  • IsPrimary fields (contact, phone, email) become read-only once set.
  • Audit tracking now available for Full Profile category configurations.

Mobile updates:

  • Ability to switch between multiple active employments.
  • Save profile contacts directly to phone contacts.
  • Performance forms link to latest profile cards.
  • Enhanced proxy access security.

The user experience is now unified across desktop and mobile — a key prerequisite for AI-driven contextual insights.

Platform, Extensibility & Identity

Platform capabilities continue to expand quietly but significantly.

  • Job Profile Builder and Talent Intelligence Hub : Available by Default on New Tenants. 💪
  • MFA for critical transactions : optional multi-factor verification for sensitive actions.
  • Identity & Access Management (RBP) : collapsible search, cleaner labels, improved tooltips.
  • Instance Refresh Tool : new Check Quota option, reduced scheduling window to 3 months.
  • Public Links for Hosting Static Content : A new self-service capability -- upload static content and generate public links directly from a new tool in the Admin Center.
  • Extensibility Wizard on SAP BTP : enables in-app and side-by-side extensions.
  • Long-Time Login : Now users, with long-time login, users can remain logged in for up to 3 months without needing to re-authenticate.
  • People Analytics Product Name Is No Longer in Use : "Stories in People Analytics" is changed to "Story reports".

These backend improvements give administrators more control and transparency in managing large, multi-tenant environments.

Deprecations & End-of-Maintenance

Action: Review these components before 2026.

Joule & GenAI Positioning

While this release is primarily functional, the AI foundation is unmistakable.

  • Strengthened data validations and consistent rule contexts ensure Joule consumes clean data.
  • Full Profile redesign supports contextual, skill-aware insights for AI assistants.
  • Extensibility Wizard simplifies integration of Joule skills and AI extensions.
  • Talent Intelligence Hub updates (timeline, proficiency visibility, “Not Rated” option) enhance semantic data for AI reasoning.
  • New transactional Joule use case — View Time Off Instructions (July 2025) — moves from navigation to transactional execution.

Final Take

If the 1H 2025 release was about launching Joule and introducing new AI ideas, 2H 2025 is about making the system ready for them.

UI modernization, better validation, and deprecation cleanup might not sound glamorous, but they decide how well your environment supports AI and analytics tomorrow.

  • Move fully to the latest People Profile.
  • Review and clean up inactive employment and dependent data.
  • Validate and update Quick Actions and workflows.
  • Plan for deprecations before 2026.
  • Start adopting the BTP Extensibility Wizard for future extensions.

2H 2025 is a foundation release — solid, stable, and designed to make your system Joule-ready by default.

Take time to explore these features in your preview environment, adjust configurations as needed, and collaborate with your recruiting teams to ensure a smooth rollout and optimal impact.

For full technical documentation, visit the SAP SuccessFactors What's New Viewer

For this release, I tried something different. Instead of writing separate blogs for each module, I focused on the most meaningful and interesting upgrades — the ones that actually matter. I’d love to hear what you think. Should I stick with this format or go back to module-wise blogs? If you enjoyed it, a kudo would mean a lot.

entry.title: Identity and Access Management with Microsoft Entra, Part III: SuccessFactors and Role Provisioning
entry.content:
Part II of this blog series took a technical deep-dive into a hybrid scenario for managing identities and their access across SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) and S/4HANA on-premise. Part III enhances the scenario by introducing SAP SuccessFactors (SF) as the source for employee and user data, and leverages the new capabilities in Entra for SCIM-based provisioning to SAP Cloud Identity Service (CIS) supporting groups to streamline end-to-end role assignments in the connected SAP ABAP backend.

Scenario Overview

Part III introduces substantial changes and enhancements to the scenario in part II:

  • Microsoft Entra and Active Directory (AD) were the primary and authoritative systems (aka "source of authority", SOA) for identity data in part II. For many organizations, however, the trusted SOA for identities is a Human Resource Information System (HRIS) such as SAP SuccessFactors (SF), which will be added to the scenario in this part, and where new employees are now onboarded.
  • Identity creation, updates, and deprovisioning are now driven by HR events (e.g., hiring, role changes, terminations) from SF. AD and Entra become downstream provisioning targets in this scenario. Because users require access to SAP from SAP GUI on their corporate AD domain-joined workstation using Kerberos/SNC-based single sign-on (SSO, see part II), the solution architecture in this scenario integrates SF with the SAP SuccessFactors to Active Directory user provisioning connector from the Microsoft Entra App Gallery. This pre-built, cloud-based solution supports inbound- or HR-driven provisioning of new employees from SF to AD through Entra. New users provisioned to AD by this connector will be synchronized to Entra with the existing setup of the Microsoft Entra Cloud Sync Provisioning Agent from part II of this blog series that runs on the Domain Controller (DC) in our fictitious company BestRun's corporate network.
  • Part II focused on the automation of provisioning the user's identity data. The user's authorization in the SAP backend (we used role SAP_BC_ABAP_DEVELOPER_5 as an example) was still managed manually by assigning the user to the equally named group "SAP_BC_ABAP_DEVELOPER_5" in the CIS tenant (see step 10.20 in part II). Also the group in CIS had to be created manually in the previous part of the scenario (see steps 9.17-9.19). This approach may work for a few backend authorizations, but won't scale for a larger number of connected systems and applications with complex authorization models. A key objective in this scenario is to fully automate end-to-end provisioning and deprovisioning of the user's authorizations, which includes the synchronization of backend roles and their corresponding groups in CIS and Entra, as well as the memberships of users to these groups, that ultimately assigns them to the backend roles. The updated version of the SAP CIS connector from the Microsoft Entra App Galley now enables automated provisioning of groups and their entitlements as memberships from Entra to CIS. This new feature in the SCIM (System for Cross-domain Identity Management, IETF RFCs 7642, 7643 and 7644)-compliant outbound provisioning connector in Entra streamlines the end-to-end lifecycle management for authorizations in the scenario. By assigning the new user to a group representing the PFCG role in the SAP ABAP system, this group and the user's membership are now also automatically provisioned to CIS, and from there to the backend system. Similar to part II, the group in Entra and CIS is mapped to the PFCG role by using the same name.

Figure 1 illustrates the SOA for the IAM entities in the scenario:

Figure 1

 

Although SOA for identity data moves to SF, the connected SAP system remains the authority for the definition of the roles that can be assigned in the scenario. Managing the actual assignment of users to these roles through access packages and approval workflows remains the responsibility of Entra ID Governance. With no single SOA for users, groups and roles centralized at one place in the system landscape, figure 2 shows the updated and newly introduced system components based on the existing setup from part II, and illustrates the steps of the provisioning flow for a new onboarded employee requesting access to a role in the corporate SAP system:

 

Figure 2

 

 

 

  1. CIS is responsible to integrate the connected SAP systems following this reference architecture. It synchronizes the role from the backend (SAP_BC_EPM_DEMO in this scenario) with the SAP Application Server ABAP connector configured as a Source System in BestRun's CIS tenant Identity Provisioning Service (IPS) which results in creating a group with the same name in the tenant's local directory. Connectivity from CIS to the SAP system on-premises remains unchanged from part II and is established via the connectivity service in BTP and the SAP Cloud Connector deployed in the corporate network.
  2. CIS also takes care for creating the group in Entra by provisioning it with the Entra ID connector configured as a target system in the CIS tenant. This connector uses the Microsoft Graph API to manage groups in Entra.
  3. The HR admin adds a new employee record in SF for the user in the sceanrio, Linda Larson. 
  4. The SAP SuccessFactors to Active Directory user provisioning connector picks up the new employee record by calling the SF Employee Central OData API endpoints to query for new or updated data.
  5. The connector then provisions a user account for the new employee Linda in BestRun's corporate AD via Entra Cloud Sync and the Entra Provisioning Agent on the DC.
  6. With Entra Cloud Sync configured in part II to synchronize AD with the Entra tenant, the new account in the corporate AD is also provisioned to BestRun's Entra ID tenant.
  7. Linda starts a request for the SAP EPM access package with the MyAccess portal. For this initial login to Entra, Linda can use the self-service password reset (SSPR) feature in Entra to set her new Entra user account's password. With password writeback enabled in Entra Cloud Sync and SSPR to use password writeback, Linda's initial password reset or any future changes of her password are synchronized back to BestRun's on-premises AD as well. By completing the request, Linda is assigned to the access package resources, and becomes a member in the SAP_BC_EPM_DEMO group in Entra. To keep things simple, the access package policy requires no approval steps in this scenario.
  8. The SAP CIS connector enterprise app is configured to perform all operations (create/update/delete) on new or existing user objects, but to skip creation on groups. Otherwise, Entra would try to create the same group again in CIS that has already been created in step 1, which would result in a naming conflict. Instead, it creates a new user account for Linda in CIS, but only updates her membership to the SAP_BC_EPM_DEMO group in BestRun's CIS tenant.
    In addition to the new support for groups in the new version of the SAP CIS connector, authentication to CIS no longer uses basic authentication that sends static credentials with every request. Instead, short‑lived tokens with scoped, limited privileges using the OAuth 2.0 client credentials grant flow enhance security over basic authentication.
  9. Provisioning to the SAP backend with the already existing SAP Application Server ABAP connector configured as a Target System in IPS starts by reading the new user and her group membership from the CIS tenant's local directory, and creating the new user in SAP as well as assigning this user to the corresponding SAP_BC_EPM_DEMO role.
  10. Finally, Linda can login to BestRun's corporate AD from her workstation, obtains a Kerberos token from the DC, and uses it to securely single sign-on to the backend from SAP GUI and the SAP Secure Login Client. This requires mapping of her user principal name (UPN) in AD to her SAP user, which has already been configured in the mappings of the SAP CIS connector in Entra (see step 6.18 in part II) and the transformation of the SAP Application Server ABAP target system in IPS (see step 9.12 in part II).

If you want to see the scenario in action, tune into the recording from our latest online session (in german language) with the DSAG TG "SAP IAM Strategie mit Microsoft"  from October 7th, or check out episode 263 from @Holger-Bruchelt SAP on Azure video podcast.

Prerequisites and lab setup

You can continue to use all subscriptions, systems and tenants from your lab in part II, because all prerequisites also apply for this scenario. In addition, make sure that you meet the following prerequisites to successfully implement the enhanced scope of this scenario:

  • Administrative access to an SF instance with permissions to setup provisioning credentials and onboard new employees.
  • An SCI tenant in a matching region of your BTP subaccount for on-premise connectivity that has Microsoft Entra ID as a target system enabled.
  • An Entra ID tenant with self-service password reset (SSPR) enabled and Entra Connect cloud sync configured for SSPR writeback to the AD in the scenario.
  • Re-run steps 9.1 to 9.10 of part II in your CIS tenatn with the updated file LocalDirectory.json for the LocalDirectory source system, and the updated file SAPA4H_IPS.json for the SAPA4H target system. The updated files apply minor changes to the transformations of both systems based on valuable feedback in the comments to part II. The customAttributes are no longer used to carry over the values for the SAP user name and SNC mapping from Entra to CIS. Instead, the extension attribute sapUserName is used, and construction of the SNC mapping has moved from Entra to the transformation of the SAPA4H target systems (lines 13 to 28).
Note 📢📢📢

This tutorial extends and updates the scenario from part II. Any components and their configurations that are not added or changed in this scenario, such as the SAP Cloud Connector or Active Directory, are not covered in this tutorial. If you arrived here and have not completed part II, please do so first, and then come back again.

As before, supporting files for this tutorial can be found in the blog series GitHub repository. Now let's get started with setting up the provisioning of new employees from SAP SuccessFactors to Entra.

Create API User in SuccessFactors for provisioning to Entra

Calling the SF OData APIs from both SF connector apps (Entra & AD) requires an API User in your SF instance who has the appropriate permissions to retrieve the required entities and their attributes.

Setup provisioning from SuccessFactors to Active Directory

The new API user's credentials are now being used to setup the SAP SuccessFactors connector for provisioning new employees to BestRun's corporate AD.  This ensures that every employee managed in SF also gets a user account in AD which is required for SSO via SNC and Kerberos when accessing BestRun's SAP system(s) from a corporate AD domain-joined workstation.

Provision the PFCG roles as groups to Entra

To continue with the configuration in Entra ID Governance for the SAP EPM access package which includes the SAP_BC_EPM_DEMO, this group must be provisioned first from the SAP system via CIS to Entra. We'll explore more sophisticated mechanisms for the employee onboarding process and initial login experience with Entra ID Governance lifecycle workflows in one of the next parts of this blog series.

entry.title: Second Half 2025 Release: What's new in SAP SuccessFactors solutions for Workforce Management
entry.content:
Time keeps moving, and so does innovation in SAP SuccessFactors solutions. The second half 2025 release delivers a powerful set of enhancements designed to simplify how organizations track, manage, and schedule time. In this blog, I’ll cover the key highlights across SAP SuccessFactors Time Tracking, Employee Central, and the newly introduced SAP SuccessFactors Workforce Scheduling solution. For a full overview, be sure to check out the ‘What’s New Viewer’.

Before diving into the details, there’s a major milestone worth celebrating: the introduction of SAP SuccessFactors Workforce Scheduling, expanding SAP’s capabilities into intelligent, demand-driven shift planning. Combined with new advancements in time tracking accuracy, compliance, and leave management, these updates continue to help organizations streamline processes, empower employees, and align workforce planning with business goals.

This evolution also signals our transition from “Time Management” to the broader category of “Workforce Management.” At SAP SuccessFactors, we are committed to empowering organizations with a complete and connected approach to workforce management. Our solutions have long supported global absence management and comprehensive time tracking, helping hourly, shift-based, and deskless employees stay productive and compliant across industries and geographies. With customers in 195 countries and across more than 29 industries, we bring a truly global perspective to how work gets done. Now, with the introduction of SAP SuccessFactors Workforce Scheduling, we are taking workforce management to the next level.

Enhancing compliance, accuracy, and transparency

This release brings several key updates that enhance compliance, improve audit readiness, and simplify time tracking for employees and administrators.

With the new geofencing feature in time tracking, employees can now clock in and out only when physically present at their designated work location. Geofences can be defined for specific groups, providing real-time visibility into proximity to authorized areas. This capability helps enforce location-based policies, ensuring accurate and compliant time recording across distributed teams.

Geofencing

Employees can now also generate a time sheet change audit report directly from the time sheet interface. This allows both employees and managers to review any edits or updates made to a time sheet, improving transparency and ensuring data accuracy during audits or investigations.

Time sheet change audit report

Advancing absence and leave management

The second half 2025 release also delivers meaningful updates to SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central Time Management, helping organizations stay compliant with country-specific regulations and automate complex leave processes.

With the new Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) enhancement, organizations in the United States (US) can now seamlessly connect with FMLA service providers to automate leave deductions and inbound data sharing such as case IDs and dates. This ensures greater accuracy in leave tracking and reduces manual administrative effort.

Family and Medical Leave Act

In addition, employees in Australia can now accrue and deduct leave in full-week units, aligning with local labor regulations and simplifying compliance management for HR teams.

Leave in full-week units

To further streamline payroll processes, a new automated payout capability enables time account balances to be paid out automatically at the end of a pay period once defined thresholds are reached. This enhancement supports multiple pay components, ensuring timely and accurate employee payments. Read more here: Payout with Flexible Pay Components using Periodic Updates – 2H 2025

Introducing SAP SuccessFactors Workforce Scheduling

This release marks the debut of SAP SuccessFactors Workforce Scheduling, designed for manufacturing and production industries. The solution will be available for early adopters in December 2025 and is planned for general availability later in 2026.

The solution supports demand-driven workforce planning, allowing organizations to create weekly or monthly shift plans that align with operational requirements and employee skills. By optimizing scheduling and providing real-time visibility into workforce availability, organizations can minimize downtime, improve productivity, and better align labor supply with business demand.

To learn more, watch the virtual session from Success Connect at SAP Connect - Smarter scheduling: Inside SAP’s new innovation in workforce management

SAP SuccessFactors Workforce Scheduling

You can explore all the new enhancements for SAP SuccessFactors Time Tracking and Employee Central Time Management in the 'What’s New Viewer.' Information about SAP SuccessFactors Workforce Scheduling will be available at launch in December 2025.

For additional release information and assets, visit the SAP SuccessFactors community page.

entry.title: Second Half 2025 Release: Continued innovations in SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central Payroll (ECP)

Hello Everyone!

Following the groundbreaking innovations in Business AI and automation from our 1H2025 release (read the blog here), we’re thrilled to unveil the new capabilities in the second half 2025 release of SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central Payroll (ECP). Below are the key highlights, but be sure to explore the What's New Viewer for the complete release notes and full details on everything we’re delivering.

AI-enabled “Explain my pay statement” comes to Germany, Netherlands and Mexico

In this release, we’re expanding the AI-enabled "Explain my pay statement" feature to Germany, the Netherlands, and Mexico, following its successful launch in the USA, UK, and Australia in 1H2025. With this feature, employees can effortlessly understand their pay statements by asking Joule, SAP’s AI copilot, questions like, “Compare my current and previous pay statements” or “Explain a specific deduction.” This reduces HR inquiries and tickets by up to 50%, while significantly boosting employee satisfaction. Joule’s responses are tailored to the company’s policy documents for accurate, personalized insights.

For more information on this feature see the “What’s New Viewer”


[Screenshot] ‘Explain my pay statement’ feature now supports Mexico in Spanish language: Prompt “Explain my deductions”

Addition of ad-hoc off cycle application to the Enhanced Payroll Control Center (PCC)

The addition of ad-hoc off-cycle application in the Enhanced Payroll Control Center (released in 1H2025) fills the gap in payroll processing by enabling the non-routine adjustments (e.g., Bonuses, corrections, etc.) outside the standard cycles. This allows running the payroll calculations and making adjustments at any time. This is particularly useful for addressing urgent issues such as missed payments, corrections to employee data, or unforeseen expenses that need immediate attention. With the addition of this capability, the enhanced PCC handles the payroll scenarios end-to-end.

For more information on this feature see the “What’s New Viewer”

Enhanced Payroll Information in the new People Profile (PPX)

We are enhancing the visibility of payroll-related information in the updated People Profile, which allows users to quickly locate specific details, enhancing efficiency and reducing clutter.  Each configured category within the payroll information section will now be presented individually as a separate card within the People Profile. Also, the payroll administrators will get information to the last replication status of employee master data, ensuring up-to-date and accurate information.

For more information on this feature see the “What’s New Viewer”

When you initiate onboarding for internal employees the default process is for the employee’s employee central record to be updated before the onboarding process is initiated.  What is meant by that is a future date record is inserted into job and compensation information. Once the workflow is approved for this job/compensation information change then an onboarding process can be initiated.  Some customers like to see all of the data in MPH before a record is created in job and compensation. An onboarding process can still be triggered after MPH, please see this article.

In this blog we will look at how you can use the ‘Define Eligibility for Onboarding Initiation’ rule to send an internal employee or candidate direct to MPH, whilst still having the onboarding integration for other candidates.  In our example we want would like to be able to send all internal hires to go to MPH and for external hires on the same requisition to be able to initiate onboarding.  Up until now this has been a challenge for candidates on the same requisition.
